prompt:
[INST] Character Info: The Hatter: Eccentric and verbose, delighting in riddles and paradoxes, speaking in a rapid, scattered manner with little regard for coherence.
The Dormouse: Sleepy and barely coherent, often trailing off mid-sentence or dozing off during conversations.
Hare: Manic and unpredictable, often jumping between topics mid-sentence, with a preference for nonsense over reason.
Alice: A curious, polite, and occasionally stubborn girl, asking endless questions and trying to apply logic to an illogical world.


Dialogue History: Alice: But why did they live at the bottom of a well?
Hare: Take some more tea,
Alice: I've had nothing yet, so I can't take more.
The Hatter: You mean you can't take _less_, it's very easy to take _more_ than nothing.
Alice: Nobody asked _your_ opinion,
The Hatter: Who's making personal remarks now?
Alice: Why did they live at the bottom of a well?
The Dormouse: It was a treacle-well.
Alice: There's no such thing!
The Dormouse: If you can't be civil, you'd better finish the story for yourself.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Alice: No, please go on! I won't interrupt again. I dare say there may be _one_.

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: The Frog-Footman: A sluggish and sleepy servant, speaking in a slow, drawling manner, often indifferent to the chaos around him.
The Duchess: Erratic and overly familiar, prone to moralizing and finding lessons in everything, regardless of whether they make sense.
Alice: A curious, polite, and occasionally stubborn girl, asking endless questions and trying to apply logic to an illogical world.
The Fish-Footman: A formal and slightly dim-witted messenger, prone to repeating himself and adhering strictly to nonsensical etiquette.
The Cat: Mischievous and cryptic, speaking in riddles and grinning as if always in on a joke that no one else understands.


Dialogue History: The Fish-Footman: For the Duchess. An invitation from the Queen to play croquet.
The Frog-Footman: From the Queen. An invitation for the Duchess to play croquet.
The Frog-Footman: There's no sort of use in knocking, and that for two reasons. First, because I'm on the same side of the door as you are; secondly, because they're making such a noise inside, no one could possibly hear you.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Alice: Please, then, how am I to get in?

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: The Gryphon: Loud and authoritative, with a tendency to boast and order others around, though not particularly mean-spirited.
The Mock Turtle: A melancholic and overly sentimental character who speaks in wistful, drawn-out tales of past glories that may not have actually happened.
Alice: A curious, polite, and occasionally stubborn girl, asking endless questions and trying to apply logic to an illogical world.


Dialogue History: The Mock Turtle: Oh, as to the whiting, they--you've seen them, of course?
Alice: Yes, I've often seen them at dinn--
The Mock Turtle: I don't know where Dinn may be, but if you've seen them so often, of course you know what they're like.
Alice: I believe so, They have their tails in their mouths--and they're all over crumbs.
The Mock Turtle: You're wrong about the crumbs, crumbs would all wash off in the sea. But they _have_ their tails in their mouths; and the reason is--
The Mock Turtle: Tell her about the reason and all that,
The Gryphon: The reason is, that they _would_ go with the lobsters to the dance. So they got thrown out to sea. So they had to fall a long way. So they got their tails fast in their mouths. So they couldn't get them out again. That's all.
Alice: Thank you, it's very interesting. I never knew so much about a whiting before.
The Gryphon: I can tell you more than that, if you like, Do you know why it's called a whiting?
Alice: I never thought about it, Why?

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: The Gryphon: _It does the boots and shoes_,

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: The King Of Hearts: A bumbling yet well-intentioned ruler, easily overshadowed by his domineering wife, trying to maintain order with little success.
The Queen: A tyrannical and short-tempered ruler, quick to anger and shout absurd orders, often demanding immediate execution of perceived offenders.
The White Rabbit: A nervous, perpetually late creature, prone to panicked exclamations and hurried speech, always worried about keeping on schedule.
Alice: A curious, polite, and occasionally stubborn girl, asking endless questions and trying to apply logic to an illogical world.
The Knave Of Hearts: A sly and evasive character, skilled at deflecting accusations and speaking in half-truths, always trying to avoid trouble.


Dialogue History: The Queen: What's in it?
The White Rabbit: I haven't opened it yet, but it seems to be a letter, written by the prisoner to--to somebody.
The King Of Hearts: It must have been that, unless it was written to nobody, which isn't usual, you know.
The White Rabbit: It isn't directed at all, in fact, there's nothing written on the _outside_. It isn't a letter, after all: it's a set of verses. No, they're not, and that's the queerest thing about it.
The King Of Hearts: He must have imitated somebody else's hand,
The Knave Of Hearts: Please your Majesty, I didn't write it, and they can't prove I did: there's no name signed at the end.
The King Of Hearts: If you didn't sign it, that only makes the matter worse. You _must_ have meant some mischief, or else you'd have signed your name like an honest man.
The Queen: That _proves_ his guilt,
Alice: It proves nothing of the sort! Why, you don't even know what they're about!
The King Of Hearts: Read them,

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: The White Rabbit: Where shall I begin, please your Majesty?

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: The Frog-Footman: A sluggish and sleepy servant, speaking in a slow, drawling manner, often indifferent to the chaos around him.
The Duchess: Erratic and overly familiar, prone to moralizing and finding lessons in everything, regardless of whether they make sense.
Alice: A curious, polite, and occasionally stubborn girl, asking endless questions and trying to apply logic to an illogical world.
The Fish-Footman: A formal and slightly dim-witted messenger, prone to repeating himself and adhering strictly to nonsensical etiquette.
The Cat: Mischievous and cryptic, speaking in riddles and grinning as if always in on a joke that no one else understands.


Dialogue History: The Frog-Footman: I shall sit here, till tomorrow--
The Frog-Footman: --or next day, maybe,
Alice: How am I to get in?
The Frog-Footman: _Are_ you to get in at all? That's the first question, you know.
Alice: It's really dreadful, the way all the creatures argue. It's enough to drive one crazy!
The Frog-Footman: I shall sit here, on and off, for days and days.
Alice: But what am _I_ to do?
The Frog-Footman: Anything you like,
Alice: Oh, there's no use in talking to him, he's perfectly idiotic!
Alice: There's certainly too much pepper in that soup!

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Alice: Please would you tell me, why your cat grins like that?

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: The Hatter: Eccentric and verbose, delighting in riddles and paradoxes, speaking in a rapid, scattered manner with little regard for coherence.
The Dormouse: Sleepy and barely coherent, often trailing off mid-sentence or dozing off during conversations.
Hare: Manic and unpredictable, often jumping between topics mid-sentence, with a preference for nonsense over reason.
Alice: A curious, polite, and occasionally stubborn girl, asking endless questions and trying to apply logic to an illogical world.


Dialogue History: Alice: Perhaps not, but I know I have to beat time when I learn music.
The Hatter: Ah! that accounts for it, He won't stand beating. Now, if you only kept on good terms with him, he'd do almost anything you liked with the clock. For instance, suppose it were nine o'clock in the morning, just time to begin lessons: you'd only have to whisper a hint to Time, and round goes the clock in a twinkling! Half-past one, time for dinner!
Hare: I only wish it was,
Alice: That would be grand, certainly, but then--I shouldn't be hungry for it, you know.
The Hatter: Not at first, perhaps, but you could keep it to half-past one as long as you liked.
Alice: Is that the way _you_ manage?
The Hatter: Not I! We quarrelled last March--just before _he_ went mad, you know-- --it was at the great concert given by the Queen of Hearts, and I had to sing You know the song, perhaps?
Alice: I've heard something like it,
The Hatter: It goes on, you know, in this way:--
The Dormouse: _Twinkle, twinkle, twinkle, twinkle_--

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: The Hatter: Well, I'd hardly finished the first verse, when the Queen jumped up and bawled out, 'He's murdering the time! Off with his head!'

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: The Frog-Footman: A sluggish and sleepy servant, speaking in a slow, drawling manner, often indifferent to the chaos around him.
The Duchess: Erratic and overly familiar, prone to moralizing and finding lessons in everything, regardless of whether they make sense.
Alice: A curious, polite, and occasionally stubborn girl, asking endless questions and trying to apply logic to an illogical world.
The Fish-Footman: A formal and slightly dim-witted messenger, prone to repeating himself and adhering strictly to nonsensical etiquette.
The Cat: Mischievous and cryptic, speaking in riddles and grinning as if always in on a joke that no one else understands.


Dialogue History: Alice: Oh, there's no use in talking to him, he's perfectly idiotic!
Alice: There's certainly too much pepper in that soup!
Alice: Please would you tell me, why your cat grins like that?
The Duchess: It's a Cheshire cat, and that's why. Pig!
Alice: I didn't know that Cheshire cats always grinned; in fact, I didn't know that cats _could_ grin.
The Duchess: They all can, and most of 'em do.
Alice: I don't know of any that do,
The Duchess: You don't know much, and that's a fact.
Alice: Oh, _please_ mind what you're doing! Oh, there goes his _precious_ nose!
The Duchess: If everybody minded their own business, the world would go round a deal faster than it does.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Alice: Which would _not_ be an advantage, Just think of what work it would make with the day and night! You see the earth takes twenty-four hours to turn round on its axis--

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: The Hatter: Eccentric and verbose, delighting in riddles and paradoxes, speaking in a rapid, scattered manner with little regard for coherence.
The King Of Hearts: A bumbling yet well-intentioned ruler, easily overshadowed by his domineering wife, trying to maintain order with little success.
The Gryphon: Loud and authoritative, with a tendency to boast and order others around, though not particularly mean-spirited.
The Queen: A tyrannical and short-tempered ruler, quick to anger and shout absurd orders, often demanding immediate execution of perceived offenders.
The Cook: Violent and chaotic, prone to throwing things and shouting, with little regard for order or safety.
The White Rabbit: A nervous, perpetually late creature, prone to panicked exclamations and hurried speech, always worried about keeping on schedule.
The Dormouse: Sleepy and barely coherent, often trailing off mid-sentence or dozing off during conversations.
Alice: A curious, polite, and occasionally stubborn girl, asking endless questions and trying to apply logic to an illogical world.
Hare: Manic and unpredictable, often jumping between topics mid-sentence, with a preference for nonsense over reason.


Dialogue History: The King Of Hearts: _Stolen!_
The Hatter: I keep them to sell, I've none of my own. I'm a hatter.
The King Of Hearts: Give your evidence, and don't be nervous, or I'll have you executed on the spot.
The Dormouse: I wish you wouldn't squeeze so. I can hardly breathe.
Alice: I can't help it, I'm growing.
The Dormouse: You've no right to grow _here_,
Alice: Don't talk nonsense, you know you're growing too.
The Dormouse: Yes, but _I_ grow at a reasonable pace, not in that ridiculous fashion.
The Queen: Bring me the list of the singers in the last concert!
The King Of Hearts: Give your evidence, or I'll have you executed, whether you're nervous or not.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: The Hatter: I'm a poor man, your Majesty, --and I hadn't begun my tea--not above a week or so--and what with the bread-and-butter getting so thin--and the twinkling of the tea--
